title: The works of Professor Wilson of the University of Edinburgh,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: The verra claes o' a callant noo that has been found porin ower an auld ballad, maun be fumigated afore he is suffered to re-enter the school, — he maun perform quaranteen, sir, like a ship frae Constantinople or Smyrna, afore the passengers are alloo'd to land on our untainted shores.

title: Noctes ambrosianæ,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: He ought to go to Smyrna.

title: Bohemian days;
author: Tadlock, Clara Moyse.
snippet: It would not be safe to go anydistance away from the towns, and woe to the shipwrecked !Even at Smyrna, last year, two Englishmen were shot, up inthe Castle on that hill bac'K of the city."

title: Bohemian days;
author: Tadlock, Clara Moyse.
snippet: — "But look your last on Smyrna," forit was almost invisible.

title: Bohemian days;
author: Tadlock, Clara Moyse.
snippet: SMYRNA— ISLES OF THE MGEAN SEA 311over a book, my dear sir, or in a superficial but earnest glanceof an hour take in its salient points."

title: Bohemian days;
author: Tadlock, Clara Moyse.
snippet: 309this dance, when not ordering the others about, and to seeher wabbling from one foot to the other with preternaturalgravity and importance, shaking flabbily, like an immenseturned-out mold of jelly — oh, it was too funny ! — My smileamidst the general solemnity was also miicli too funny, Ifound out when Candace's attention was attracted to the new" looker on " in Smyrna, for with a frighful scowl at me sheordered the door shut immediately.

title: Bohemian days;
author: Tadlock, Clara Moyse.
snippet: Pagus, the back-ground of Smyrna, fromwhich we looked down and out upon the magnificent harbor, gulf, mountains and city.

title: Bohemian days;
author: Tadlock, Clara Moyse.
snippet: Smyrna has a slave market owned by Jews, where negrOes,men, women and children, are put up for sale, and generallybranded on the forehead.

title: Bohemian days;
author: Tadlock, Clara Moyse.
snippet: We were no longer in Europe, having become for thenonce inhabitants of Asia — we were at Smyrna (Ismir), thebirth-place of Homer, the land of figs, of dates, of sweetmeats, of mosques and minarets ; the greatest commercialport of Asiatic Turkey, with its mountains sloping to thewater's edge; cypress-shaded, turban-crowned tombs; prettyrural kiosks, embowered in shrubbery, where ladies of theharem amused themselves ; and guarded upper windows,from which bright eyes were watching us ! From the Sortfloated the red flag of Turkey.

title: Bohemian days;
author: Tadlock, Clara Moyse.
snippet: As we approached Smyrna the waters of the Meanderchanged the color of the Gulf from a deep blue to a lightgreen, while beyond that again it was bright violet, with thesun gleaming and glinting as if it wore upon its bosom athousand diamonds.

title: Wayside notes and fireside thoughts.
author: South, Eudora Lindsay.
snippet: Mr. Benjamin, the only young gentleman of the party, here left us, and Miss Powers, the missionary to Smyrna, inquired of Mr. K. where he was from.

title: Wayside notes and fireside thoughts.
author: South, Eudora Lindsay.
snippet: " She is on her way to Smyrna, as a missionary."

title: Our trip to Europe,
author: Simmonds, Irene
snippet: Today we are anchored in the harbor of Smyrna, will be here till tomorrow night, and will then sail for Athens.

title: Library notes,
author: Russell, A. P.
snippet: Feeling that he could not speak with authority on the subject of pest- houses until he had experienced the discipline of one, he went to Smyrna, sought out a soul ship, and sailed in her for Venice.

title: Library notes,
author: Russell, A. P.
snippet: He proceeded thence to Malta, Zante, Smyrna, and Constantinople, visiting prisons, pest-houses, and hospitals, and in the two latter cities gratuitously dispensing his medical services, often with great benefit to the poor.

title: Little memoirs of the eighteenth century,
author: Paston, George
snippet: It was not until the end of October that our hero found himself able to set out on his projected tour in Greece, which was to include visits to Nicea, the lake of ApoUonia, Sestos and Abydos, the plain of Troy, Smyrna, Ephesus, the Grecian islands, Athens, and the Morea, He had already collected a large number of valuable drawings  of Constantinople, its environs, and the costumes of the country, and carried with him on his journey through Greece a clever French artist, M. Preaux, who had been employed by the Comte de Choiseul ; and being unable to return to his own country, was glad to make the proposed  tour, during which he was to execute drawings of the most interesting buildings and ruins upon very moderate conditions.

title: Addresses and letters of travel,
author: Nye, Stephen Girard
snippet: Smyrna and Constantinople are great centers of the rug industry.

title: Addresses and letters of travel,
author: Nye, Stephen Girard
snippet: At Smyrna came the news that Constantinople was under quarantine, which would detain us on board ship for two days going in and ten days coming out, so Constantinople  is cut out and at Smyrna we reshipped direct to Pirseus, the port of Athens, where we landed at 2 p.

title: Addresses and letters of travel,
author: Nye, Stephen Girard
snippet: At Smyrna came the news that Constantinople was under quarantine, which would detain us on board ship for two days going in and ten days coming out, so Constantinople  is cut out and at Smyrna we reshipped direct to Pirseus, the port of Athens, where we landed at 2 p.

title: St. Paul's to St. Sophia;
author: McCormick, Richard C.
snippet: I well remember when I saw it for the first time, on my arrival at Smyrna, how all my juvenile fancies of the East came rushing into mind.

title: Some friends of mine,
author: Lucas, E. V.
snippet: You may well imagine that this anxiety of Carrigaholt  to purchase (not only the scenery) l)ut the many dramatis personce belonging to his dreams, with all their goodness and graces complete, necessarily gave an immense  stimulus to the trade and intrigue of Smyrna, and created a demand for human virtues which the moral resources of the place were totally inadequate to supply.

title: Some friends of mine,
author: Lucas, E. V.
snippet: Our friend afterwards went by sea to Smyrna, and there he now was in his glory.

title: Some friends of mine,
author: Lucas, E. V.
snippet: "X ^ THEN I was there, our friend Carrigaholt had im- ' ' ported himself, and his oddities as an accession to the other, and inferior wonders of Smyrna.

title: Old diaries, 1881-1901 /
author: Gower, Ronald Sutherland
snippet: Another Oxford man had joinedus at Smyrna, Farnell, full of archaeological and historicalinformation ; he is on his way to Constantinople to see thefamous sarcophagi.

title: Old diaries, 1881-1901 /
author: Gower, Ronald Sutherland
snippet: On the 2\st, wearrived off Smyrna ; in that harbour we visited the ironclad, The Inflexible, and were shown that wonderful massof floating iron and steel by Dr Atchinson and LieutenantGrenfell, and we steamed away for Constantinople thatevening.

title: Old diaries, 1881-1901 /
author: Gower, Ronald Sutherland
snippet: Writing on the last day of that year (1885) — "I havebeen permitted to live it through, with many things to makeit a year to be remembered ; for who can forget having seenfor the first time Constantinople and San Sofia, Broussaand Mount Olympus, Smyrna from its old castle top,Damascus and its mosque, Baalbec and its gloriouscolumns, Jerusalem and its squalor, but with a character allits own ; and last, but certainly not least, this old-timefamed river, with its ruins that have seen five kingdomsrise and fall, and have yet survived them all."

title: Old diaries, 1881-1901 /
author: Gower, Ronald Sutherland
snippet: At Smyrna two young Roumanian Princes had come onboard, to all intents and purposes Parisians, agreeable andwell-bred.

title: Old diaries, 1881-1901 /
author: Gower, Ronald Sutherland
snippet: Smyrna is infested by brigands ; three of thesehad been killed a few days ago, and their heads placed ona railing in front of the Governor's palace, and had onlybeen removed the morning I arrived.

title: Old diaries, 1881-1901 /
author: Gower, Ronald Sutherland
snippet: At Smyrna I had ridden up the hill crowned by theruined Castle, from whence the view of the harbour isstriking.

title: A Californian circling the globe,
author: Fuller, Henry.
snippet: We boarded the train, again full of curious people, and as we halted a few minutes in the edge of Smyrna at sunset, I looked over in a vacant field and saw fully one hundred camels lying down in rows, eating their suppers of chopped hay or straw.

title: A Californian circling the globe,
author: Fuller, Henry.
snippet: The proportion of Mohammedans  to Christians in the population is small, so marked that the Turks speak of Smyrna as "the infidel city."

title: A Californian circling the globe,
author: Fuller, Henry.
snippet: "The Malaga grapes are very good grapes but the grapes of Smyrna are better."

title: A Californian circling the globe,
author: Fuller, Henry.
snippet: We could only hope to get out of Smyrna without going through quarantine.

title: A Californian circling the globe,
author: Fuller, Henry.
snippet: The steamer cast its anchor and a small boat came from the shore flying the yellow flag of quarantine, and reported that a case of black plague had occurred, and Smyrna might be quarantined.

title: A Californian circling the globe,
author: Fuller, Henry.
snippet: As we sailed into our place of anchorage in Smyrna, I was surprised to see such a large city circling the end of the gulf the largest in Asia Minor, about 300,000 popula-

title: Later letters of Marcus Dods, D. D. (late principal of New college, Edinburgh) (1895-1909)
author: Dods, Marcus
snippet: Thank you again and again for your vivid descriptions, which have let me see the Sultan's pallid face and smell his filthy capital and enjoy the colours of Smyrna.

title: Diary, sketches and reviews,
author: Dodge, Robert. [from old catalog]
snippet: 14th — About 9 A. M., arrived at Malta ; and were de- ligted to hear that our quarantine was only for five whole days ; our time from Smyrna being counted ; so, landed in a small boat, at Fort Manuel, and there made ourselves quite comfortable, being in full view of the city of Valetta.

title: Diary, sketches and reviews,
author: Dodge, Robert. [from old catalog]
snippet: A' French frigate from Smyrna, likewise lay in quarantine, and boarded us.

title: Diary, sketches and reviews,
author: Dodge, Robert. [from old catalog]
snippet: We started from Smyrna about 11, A. M., and passed the Cape, at the mouth of the Bay, about 3, P. M.

title: Diary, sketches and reviews,
author: Dodge, Robert. [from old catalog]
snippet: — We arrived at Smyrna early this morning, and remained  six hours in view, under a bright sky, being prevented  from landing by the new quarantine regulations.

title: Diary, sketches and reviews,
author: Dodge, Robert. [from old catalog]
snippet: Received letters from my mother and S. N. D., each answered, wrote also to Tupper  to be sent by H. and also note inclosing a copy of his Venus to D. by the same hand, to be published in the Literary  world ; called in the evening on some friends and received introductions  for Smyrna.

title: Forging his chains.
author: Bidwell, George.
snippet: He tried to "beat" the Turks, was apprehended  and sentenced to four years' imprisonment at Smyrna, but not liking the quarters in Constantinople to which he had been consigned, took French leave after a few months' confinement.

title: Auld licht idylls.
author: Barrie, J. M.
snippet: Not long ago I heard him read a preface to a life of Mr. Gladstone that was being printed at Smyrna in modern Greek.

title: Waverley Novels. (Abbotsford edition.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: ' What 1 had known of Tyrrel atSmyrna, had given me much interest in him, audyou may guess it was not lessened by the distresseswhich lie had sustained through his brother's treachery.. By this fellow's means, 1 have counterplottedall his master's fine schemes.

title: Waverley Novels. (Abbotsford edition.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "Why," said Touchwood, " I was settled for sometime at Smyrna, (for I turn the penny go where Iwill—1 have done a little business even since I camehere ;) — but being at Smyrna, as I said, I becameacquainted with Francis Tyrrel."

title: Waverley Novels. (Abbotsford edition.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "Why," said Touchwood, " I was settled for sometime at Smyrna, (for I turn the penny go where Iwill—1 have done a little business even since I camehere ;) — but being at Smyrna, as I said, I becameacquainted with Francis Tyrrel."

title: Waverley Novels. (Abbotsford edition.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: " A troublesome, inquisitive old gentleman," saidTyrrel to himself; " I remember him narrowlyescaping tlie bastinado at Smyrna, for thrusting hisadvice on the Turkish cadi — and then I lie undera considerable obligation to him, giving him a sortof right to annoy me—Well, I must parry his impertinence as I can."

title: Waverley Novels. (Abbotsford edition.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: " Another time — another time," said Mr Touchwoo— "time enough before us, Mr Tyrrel —besides, at Smyrna, you talked of a lawsuit — lawis a lick-penny, Mr Tyrrel — no counsellor like thepound in purse:"" For my lawsuit," said Tyrrel, " I am fully provided."

title: Waverley Novels. (Abbotsford edition.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: " You are a conceited old woman," said MrTouchwood ; " how the devil should any one knowhow to mix spices so well as he who has beenwhere they grow ? — I have seen the sun ripeningnutmegs and cloves, and here, it can hardly fill apeascod, by Jupiter ! Ah, Tyrrel, the merry nightswe have had at Smyrna ! — Gad, I think the gammon and the good wine taste all the better in a landwhere folks hold them to be sinful indulgence —Gad, I believe many a good Moslem is of the sameopinion — that same prohibition of their prophet'sgives a flavour to the ham, and a relish to theCyprus.

title: Waverley Novels. (Abbotsford edition.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The circumstances of embarrassment, under which you foundme at Smyrna, were merely temporary—I am mostable and willing to pay my debt; and, let me add,I am most desirous to do so."

title: Waverley Novels. (Abbotsford edition.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: After the operation wasended, he could not help addressing himself to MrTouchwood, to demand whether he had not thepleasure to see a friend to whom he had been obligedwhen at Smyrna, for some kindness respecting hismoney matters ?" Not worth speaking of—not worth speaking of,"said Touchwood hastily.

author: Scott, Walter
snippet: " A troublesome, inquisitive, old gentleman," saidTyrrel to himself; " I remember him narrowlyescaping the bastinado at Smyrna, for thrusting hisadvice on the Turkish cadi—and then I lie under aconsiderable obligation to him, giving him a sort ofright to annoy me.

title: The Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott. (Supplementary volume: containing notes, historical and illustrative, by the author, glossary, etc.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: " You are a conceited old woman," said MrTouchwood; "how the devil should any one knowto mix spices so well as one that has been wherethey grow?—I have seen the sun ripeniDg nutmegsand cloves, and here, it can hardly fill a peasecod,I>y Jupiter!—Ah, Tyrrel, the merry nights we havehad at Smyrna !—Gad, I think the gammon and she_;ood wine taste all the better in a land where folkshold them to be sinful indulgences—Gad, I believemany a good Moslem is of the same opinion—thatsame prohibition of their prophets gives a flavour tothe ham, and a relish to the Cyprus.—Do you remember old Cogia Hassein, with his green turban ?—I once played him a trick, and put a pint of brandyinto his sherbet.

title: Here and there in the Home Land. England, Scotland and Ireland as seen by a Canadian. ... Profusely illustrated
author: Haight, Canniff.
snippet: Among the coffeehouses of Pall Mall was the Smyrna, of the days of theTatler and Spectator, where subscriptions were taken inby Thomson for publishing his "Seasons," etc., and at theStar and Garter tavern took place the encounter betweenLord Byron (the father of the poet) and his neighbour, Mr.Chaworth.

title: World: round it and over it ... letters ... With illustrations ... Second edition
author: Glass, Chester.
snippet: The musicwas about the same as is found all over Asia fromSmyrna to Yokohama—a monotonous jingle, and veryfew notes, neither high nor low—just the kind to send one

title: World: round it and over it ... letters ... With illustrations ... Second edition
author: Glass, Chester.
snippet: The great cities of the Turkish Empire,such as Constantinople, Smyrna, Beyroot, Damascus andJerusalem, are none of them lighted with gas.

title: World: round it and over it ... letters ... With illustrations ... Second edition
author: Glass, Chester.
snippet: We left Smyrna for Beyroot ina steamer of the Messageries Maritimes Line, anafor the whole six days' trip had delightfully warm weather.

title: World: round it and over it ... letters ... With illustrations ... Second edition
author: Glass, Chester.
snippet: vengeance hurled against other churches, a promise isgiven to Smyrna : " Be thou faithful unto death, and 1will give thee a crown of life."

title: World: round it and over it ... letters ... With illustrations ... Second edition
author: Glass, Chester.
snippet: Flourishing as a great centre of commerce at so early adate as to claim to be the birth-place of Homer, Smyrnato-day looks like a new city when compared to its comparatively modern rival, Constantinople.

title: World: round it and over it ... letters ... With illustrations ... Second edition
author: Glass, Chester.
snippet: At Smyrna we had toproduce our passports, and were a good deal delayed bythe stupid red-tape formalities to be gone through.

title: World: round it and over it ... letters ... With illustrations ... Second edition
author: Glass, Chester.
snippet: Next to Constantinople, Smyrna is the largest city inTurkey.

title: World: round it and over it ... letters ... With illustrations ... Second edition
author: Glass, Chester.
snippet: We crossed over the track taken by the wily Spartanswhen they retired to Tenedos to await the result ofthe famous wooden-horse trick, and sped our- way onto Smyrna.
